title: Creditor asking court for order to garnish my wages under ccp 706.109. how do i reply?
question: Creditor has denied request for payment arrangement. now she is going after me (the spouse) how do i reply on my answer to her request?
answers:
A person’s earnings during marriage are community property. Fam. C. §297.5, 760. A nondebtor spouse’s earnings ARE SUBJECT TO GARNISHMENT unless
1) The debt at issue was incurred before the marriage; AND
2) The relevant earnings are kept in a separate deposit account which the debtor spouse does not have access to; AND
3) The nondebtor’s earnings are not commingled with other community property; AND
4) The debt at issue is not a “necessary of life” (i.e. food, shelter, clothing…etc.)

However, an earnings withholding order alone will not be sufficient to reach the nondebtor spouse’s earnings, a court order upon noticed motion is necessary. CCP §706.109.

The same exemptions that apply to a judgment debtor’s earnings (i.e. for social security income or public benefits) apply to the earnings of the nondebtor spouse.

The next step is to object to the motion on the grounds that either the above conditions are met or the funds at issue are exempt for some reason.

I agree with what the other attorneys wrote you. I add that if you do not file bankruptcy (your spouse and you would both have to file as I understand it), you have several options:

1. You can always do nothing, which will result in 25% of your take-home pay being garnished per paycheck. This is certainly one way to pay off the debt.

2. You also have the option to oppose the garnishment in an effort to stop the garnshihment or reduce the amount retained from your paycheck. This is called a claim of exemption. You start by delivering to the Sheriff (or whoever is the levying officer) a claim of exemption. See: http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/ej160.pdf for the form and see: http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/ej155.pdf for a list of possible exemptions (not all will apply.) What happens then is that the creditor has the chance to respond and argue to the Court that your exemption claims do not apply. Ultimately, this can lead to some kind of payment plan discussion and agreement or, if no agreement can be made, the Court deciding your exemption claims.

Good luck.

Notwithstanding the state court options, you can consider relief under Chapter 7 or Chapter 13 of the bankruptcy code. You may be eligible to "discharge" or legally wipe out the debt-or- obtain a monthly payment plan that is lower than the amount of the garnishment and the sum of your other obligations.
